title: Cu-BTC/Aminated Graphite Oxide Composites As High-Efficiency CO
Capture Media
abstract: adsorption isotherms on Cu-BTC/aminated graphite oxide composites were measured in the pressure range up to 1.5 MPa at three different temperatures close to ambient. Adsorption capacity, isosteric heat of adsorption, and regenerability were investigated. They are considered as significant factors determining the practical application of materials for CO
capture. The results indicate a significant improvement in the performance of the composites as CO

adsorbents in comparison with the parent Cu-BTC MOF. Among all samples analyzed, the composite of Cu-BTC and modified graphite oxide with the highest N content (MOF/GO-U3) is the best performing sample. On its surface 13.41 mmol/g CO
was adsorbed at room temperature and 1.5 MPa. A high selectivity for CO
was found. The selectivities for CO
are governed by the properties of the MOF phase. A relatively low heat of CO
adsorption and the high degree of surface homogeneity cause that the composites can be fully regenerated and used in multicycle adsorption with the minimum energy demand.

Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are a type of microporous crystalline solids with a periodic network structure, formed by self-assembly through covalent bonds or inter-molecular forces between metal ions and organic ligands.
They have similar structure and properties to zeolites. Owing to the extremely high surface area and pore volume,
and rich and flexible surface chemistry,
MOFs have become the attractive materials for hydrogen storage,
As physical adsorbents, MOFs exhibit high CO
capacity and thus bring broad prospects, which have attracted attention of researchers.

Even though MOF materials have been presented as excellent adsorbents, their large void space is not completely utilized for gas storage because of weak interactions between the walls of MOFs and usually small gas/adsorbate molecules.
To increase the dispersive forces, other materials, microporous

can be incorporated to their structure forming composite solids. Such composites have pores similar in size to the size of a gas molecule and thus physical forces between adsorbent and adsorbate are enhanced.
These materials showed an improved porosity and adsorptive performance.

The objective of this work is an evaluation of the CO

capture capability of these new materials. The adsorption is measured at three different temperatures in a wide pressure range. The adsorption capacity, adsorption heat, and regeneration ability of adsorbents are evaluated. They are significant parameters affecting the real-life application of these materials as CO
capture media. Besides, the selectivitites for CO
are estimated. The latter two species are often present in the natural gas or flue gas from which CO
The detailed synthesis routes of the parent MOF Cu-BTC and its composites with graphite oxide (GO)
or aminated graphite oxide were reported previously.
The samples used in this study are from the same batch as those addressed in Ref.
Graphite oxide was prepared by oxidation of graphite using classic Hummers’ method.
Aminated graphite oxide was prepared by treating GO with urea.

Three different amount of urea were used. The synthesis procedures of MOF/graphite oxide or MOF/aminated graphite oxide composites were similar. GO or GO-U and MOF components were simultaneously dispersed/dissolved in the solvent by sonication. The mixture was then heated at 353 K for 24 h under shaking. The intended content of GO or GO-U in the composite was 10 wt % of the parent MOF. The composites are referred to as MOF/GO, MOF/GO-U1, MOF/GO-U2, and MOF/GO-U3, respectively. The numbers after GO-U represent the increasing amount of urea used for modification.

It is important to mention that our MOF and the composites were activated/outgassed at 393 K, which is the lower temperature than 453 K commonly used for activation of Cu-BTC and the materials which contain that MOF (membranes). This results in a lower surface area and porosity of MOF than those reported previously.
Such a behavior is linked to the not complete removal of water adsorbed on the copper centers. This residual water is responsible for lower nitrogen uptake and must also negatively affect the CO

adsorption. Knowing that GO decomposes at about 453 K, we were not able to completely activate the composites and thus for the sake of comparison, Cu-BTC MOF (HKUST-1) was activated at the same conditions.

adsorption process is reversible (see Figure 1S in the

all desorption curves have been shifted manually to better visualize the reversibility of the adsorption process. Because the desorption points overlap with those of the adsorption curve, the apparent hysteresis is not real.
The same conclusion about reversibility is reached based on the analysis of different subsequent adsorption cycles collected in Figure

. The first three isotherms have been acquired in sequence, while the fourth one - after heating the samples at 393 K for 12 h in vacuum. As seen, the curves are comparable. MOF, MOF/GO-U1, and MOF/GO-U2 show a slight decrease in the CO
capacity after the first cycle at each temperature. The change on MOF/GO-U1 is the most visible. A decrease in CO
uptake at 1.5 MPa is about 4 % at the room temperature and about 10% at 319 K. These slight variations can be caused by the strong CO
adsorption in very small pores of this composite.
Nevertheless, the fourth cycle indicates that the maximum CO
adsorption capacity can be easily restored by treating the sample in vacuum for about 12 h at 393 K. In the case of MOF/GO and MOF/GO-U3, CO
adsorption is totally reversible and no thermal treatment is necessary to recover the samples’ capacity. Therefore these samples, besides being the excellent CO
adsorbents, can be very easily regenerated with little energy demand. The excellent regenerability of our materials as CO
adsorbents also demonstrates their structural stability under used operation conditions/high pressure. Materials having the high CO
capture capacity and low energy consumption for the CO
release are most desirable for practical applications. Jones and coworkers

Climate impact of increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide
Hansen, J.; Johnson, D.; Lacis, A.; Lebedeff, S.; Lee, P.; Rind, D.; Russell, G.

The global temp. rose by 0.2 between the middle 1960's and 1980, yielding a warming of 0.4° in the past century.  This temp. increase is consistent with the calcd. greenhouse effect due to measured increases of atm. CO2.  Variations of volcanic aerosols and possibly solar luminosity appear to be primary causes of obsd. fluctuations about the mean trend of increasing temp.  The anthropogenic CO2 warming should emerge from the noise level of natural climate variability by the end of the century, and there is a high probability of warming in the 1980's.  Potential effects on climate in the 21st century include the creation of drought-prone regions in North America and Central Asia as part of a shifting of climatic zones, erosion of the West Antarctic ice sheet with a consequent worldwide rise in sea level, and opening of the fabled Northwest Passage.
Influence of natural and anthropogenic carbon dioxide sequestration on global warming
Ghommem, Mehdi; Hajj, Muhammad R.; Puri, Ishwar K.

The increase in the global surface temp. is influenced by several factors including anthropogenic and natural emissions of CO2, and the ability of natural sequestration reservoirs in the Earth's oceans and land to absorb and store it.  The CO2 absorption in these reservoirs is sensitive to changes in the global temp. and the atm. CO2 concn., thus creating a feedback loop in the Earth's ecosystem, which complicates predictions of the overall impact of rising atm. CO2 levels on global warming.  Here, we model this interaction through a pos. feedback loop and utilize general circulation models (GCM) to quantify the coupling between the carbon-cycle and the global temp.  We validate the model by comparing its predictions with those from high fidelity simulations and historical records.  Thereafter, we investigate the impact of anthropogenic CO2 sequestration on lowering the rate of increase in the global temp. and find that a redn. in global warming is more sensitive to larger sequestration fractions.  Thus, an inordinately large fraction of CO2 emissions would have to be sequestered to significantly impact global warming.

Adsorbent Materials for Carbon Dioxide Capture from Large Anthropogenic Point Sources
Choi, Sunho; Drese, Jeffrey H.; Jones, Christopher W.

A review concerning the adsorption behavior of several different classes of solid adsorbents (zeolites, activated C, calcium oxides, hydrotalcites, org./inorg. hybrids, metal-org. frameworks) to treat anthropogenic CO2 pollutant emissions is given.  Sorbents were evaluated for their equil. CO2 capacity and other important parameters (adsorption/desorption kinetics, operating windows, stability, regenerability).  The scope of currently available CO2 adsorbents and the crit. properties which ultimately affect their incorporation into large-scale sepn. processes is discussed.  Topics covered include: CO2 capture process; what makes a good adsorbent, CO2 adsorbent metrics; inorg. adsorbents (physisorbents [zeolites, activated C, chemisorbents, hydrotalcite-like compds.]); hybrid org./inorg. adsorbents (amines phys. adsorbed on oxide supports, amines covalently tethered to oxide supports, amines supported on solid org. materials, C-supported amines); metal/org. frameworks, an emerging materials class (material characteristics, CO2 adsorption capacity under dry conditions and CO2 partial pressure impact, CO2 adsorption capacity and effect of CO2 partial pressure, adsorption temp., and ΔHads); exptl. methods effect on measured adsorption properties; and concluding remarks and outlook.

Absorption of CO2 by amino acid-functionalized and traditional dicationic ionic liquids: Properties, Henry's law constants and mechanisms
Zhang, Yi; Yu, Ping; Luo, Yunbai

Six dicationic ionic liqs. (DIL) were synthesized (4 amino acid-functionalized DIL [AA-DIL] and 2 traditional DIL [T-DIL]), and detd. to effectively capture CO2 as reversible absorbents.  Their phys. properties including d., cond., thermal decompn. and glass transition temps., and viscosity, were measured.  Their CO2 absorption behavior under different pressure and temp. and under various water content, were also examd.  Results showed that CO2 absorption capacity of pure AA-DIL was heavily enhanced vs. other monocationic ionic liqs.  Mixing AA-DIL and water could be combined in a more rapid, efficient manner for CO2 gas capture, superior to using pure DIL only, due to the visible decrease in viscosity.  Temp. effect on CO2 absorption by aq. AA-DIL mixts. at ambient pressure was very obvious: when temp. increased from 30 to 50°, the capacity of the 60 wt. percent [Bis(mim)C4][Pro]2 soln. decreased from 1.52 to 0.78 mol/mol; as pressure increased to 10.0 bar, total maximal capacity decreased by >50%.  The 2 traditional DIL exhibited excellent phys. absorption vs. various monocationic ionic liqs.
A novel surface modified polyvinylidene fluoride hollow fiber membrane contactor for CO2 absorption
Rahbari-Sisakht, M.; Ismail, A. F.; Rana, D.; Matsuura, T.

A novel surface modified polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) hollow fiber membrane was fabricated via a dry-wet phased inversion process.  A surface modifying macromol. (SMM) was used as an additive in the spinning dope.  During phase inversion SMM migrates to the membrane surface and functions as both a pore former and surface modifier.  The surface modified PVDF membrane showed large pore size, higher effective surface porosity, contact angle and porosity but lower crit. water entry pressure compared to the PVDF hollow fiber membrane without SMM.  The performance of the surface modified membrane in contactor application for CO2 absorption via distd. water as absorbent was studied.  The results show that the surface modified PVDF membrane has higher performance compared to control PVDF membranes.  With the membrane prepd. from SMM in the spinning dope a max. CO2 flux of 7.7 × 10-4 mol/m2 s was achieved at 300 mL/min of absorbent flow rate, which was almost 93% more than the other membrane.  In a long-term stability study, CO2 flux was decreased only about 7.7% by using surface modified PVDF membrane during 150 h operation.
Cryogenic method for H2 and CH4 recovery from a rich CO2 stream in pre-combustion carbon capture and storage schemes
Atsonios, K.; Panopoulos, K. D.; Doukelis, A.; Koumanakos, A.; Kakaras, E.

The pre-combustion carbon capture technol. based on coal gasification or methane reforming followed by (water gas shift reactors assisted with Pd-alloys membranes) WGS-MR is considered very promising for the prodn. of a rich hydrogen stream that can be combusted in combined cycles.  However, recovery of the total H2 content is not feasible and a part of it remains in the retentate side.  The requirement for upstream high pressure operation of the necessary reforming step has a drawback: complete reforming of CH4 is not possible; thus small but significant amts. remain in the rich CO2 stream.  These CH4 amts. not only affect the efficiency of the process but also are against regulations for the allowed compn. of carbon dioxide for storage.  Therefore, an efficient purifn. step before its compression is of high importance.  The current work models a cryogenic method for the sepn. of combustibles from a rich-CO2 stream and evaluates its effects on the efficiency of the pre-combustion carbon capture system.  The modeling study is performed with AspenPlus.  A study on the effect of operating parameters of the (Purifn. & Compression Unit) PCU integration on the performance is presented.
Nguyen, Thu; Hilliard, Marcus; Rochelle, Gary T.
International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control

Amine volatility is a key screening criterion for amines to be used in CO2 capture.  Excessive volatility may result in significant economic losses and environmental impact.  It also dictates the capital cost of the water wash.  This paper reports measured amine volatility in 7 m MEA (monoethanolamine), 8 m PZ (piperazine), 7 m MDEA (n-methyldiethanolamine)/2 m PZ (piperazine), 12 m EDA (ethylenediamine), and 5 m AMP (2-amino-2-methyl-1-propanol) at 40-60 °C with lean and rich loadings giving CO2 partial pressures of 0.5 and 5 kPa at 40 °C.  The amine concns. were chosen to maximize CO2 capture capacity at acceptable viscosity.  At the lean loading condition (where volatility is of greatest interest), the amines are ranked in order of increasing volatility: 7 m MDEA/2 m PZ (6/2 ppm), 8 m PZ (8 ppm), 12 m EDA (9 ppm), 7 m MEA (31 ppm), and 5 m AMP (112 ppm).  The apparent amine partial molar excess enthalpies in these systems were estd. to range from ∼10 to 87 kJ/mol of amine.

A systematic mol. simulation study was performed to compare the sepn. of CO2/N2 and CH4/N2 mixts. in two different classes of nanoporous materials, zeolites, and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).  For this purpose, three zeolites (MFI, LTA, and DDR) and seven MOFs (Cu-BTC, MIL-47 (V), IRMOF-1, IRMOF-12, IRMOF-14, IRMOF-11, and IRMOF-13) were chosen as the representatives to compare.  From the validated force fields, both adsorption selectivity and pure CO2 and CH4 adsorption isotherms were simulated.  Although MOFs perform much better for gas storage, their sepn. performance is comparable to zeolites; for the systems with the preferable component having a larger quadrupolar moment, both zeolites and MOFs can enhance the sepn. selectivity, and in contrast they both reduce the selectivity.  Ideal adsorbed soln. theory (IAST) gives a very reasonable prediction of the mixt. adsorption isotherms both in zeolites and in MOFs if the pure component isotherms are known.  The difference in quadrupolar moment of the components is an important property that has to be considered in the selection of a membrane material.
